item.title: Wreckfest 2 Early Access Release Date Scheduled for March
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/wreckfest-2-early-access-release-date

THQ Nordic and Bugbear have announced the Early Access release date for destruction derby racer Wreckfest 2, so get ready to engage in what the two studios describe as "absolute vehicular mayhem".

Wreckfest 2 officially arrives on PC via Steam Early Access on March 20th. The game will also eventually come to consoles, although it doesn't look like the Early Access release is making it onto PS5 or Xbox Series X|S, sadly.

When it launches, Wreckfest 2 will pack in three gameplay modes: Racing, Derby, and Multiplayer. They're fairly self-explanatory, and as Early Access progresses, Bugbear says it'll also add "a completely revamped career mode that adapts to your individual playstyle".

As well as the career mode, Bugbear is also promising to add new tracks and vehicles throughout Wreckfest 2's Early Access development, and new special challenges in which you race vehicles that "were definitely never supposed to end up on a racetrack" will be introduced.

Various other features, like tournaments and mod support, are also on the cards for Early Access. Rest assured that it does sound like Wreckfest 2 has a solid core in place if you do decide to pick it up before these features have been implemented, though.

That experience involves what Bugbear and THQ Nordic describe as "full-contact racing action with no rules, just jaw-dropping moments of chaos and destruction". The sequel will sport an improved physics engine compared to the original, too.

You can check out the Early Access release date announcement trailer for Wreckfest 2 right here. It should give you a good idea of what kind of destructive action to expect from the game.

Wreckfest 2 launches for PC via Steam Early Access on March 20th. There's no word yet on when the game is coming to consoles, although it has been slated for PS5 and Xbox Series X|S as well. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Helldivers 2 Servants of Freedom Warbond to Bring Portable Hellbomb and More
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/helldivers-2-servants-of-freedom-warbond

Sony and Arrowhead Game Studios have announced a new Helldivers 2 Warbond, and if you've ever wanted the destructive power of a Hellbomb strapped to your back, this is the Warbond for you.

Like previous Helldivers 2 Warbonds, Servants of Freedom brings a bunch of new gear for you to try out, foremost among which is the B-100 Portable Hellbomb Stratagem. Like the regular Hellbomb, make sure you're nowhere near this one when it goes off.

Of course, new weapons are also coming as part of this Warbond, including the LAS-17 Double-Edge Sickle, which powers up the regular Sickle and allows it to overheat, potentially damaging both you and "everything in its path".

The secondary slot, meanwhile, gets a new GP-20 Ultimatum grenade pistol, which is "designed for closer-range use". That, given Helldivers 2's penchant for randomly murdering you in hilarious ways, sounds like a recipe for disaster to me.

Servants of Freedom also brings a new throwable weapon in the G-50 Seeker, a drone that follows along behind you and explodes near enemies when it detects them. It can also target enemies you ping.

Two new armor sets have been added, both medium sets: the IE-3 Martyr and the IE-12 Righteous. Both sets come complete with rather terrifying masked helms that will make you look like Doctor Doom, but if he fought on the side of justice, truth, and democracy (ahem).

Naturally, the Warbond comes complete with new capes, a new player title, and a new cheer as well, all of which should help you express yourself when you're taking the fight to those dastardly Terminids (or bots, or Illuminate, of course).

Elsewhere in Helldivers 2 news, chief creative officer Johan Pilestedt announced last week that he's intending to take a sabbatical from work, and that when he returns, he'll begin work on a new Arrowhead game. Exciting!

Helldivers 2 is available right now for PC and PlayStation 5, and the Servants of Freedom Warbond arrives on February 6th. You can check out our Helldivers 2 review here.

item.title: Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero Sales Break the 5m Barrier
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/dragon-ball-sparking-zero-sales-5m

Bandai Namco has announced that Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero sales have hit another big milestone, further cementing the latest Dragon Ball fighter's popularity and success.

In a post on X, the studio reveals that Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero has hit five million sales, a figure it's managed to reach in around four months.

We already knew the game was successful; it launched to the Dragon Ball series' best Steam debut ever and went on to top three million sales in its first day on release, meaning that it's picked up another two million for itself in the intervening months.

That figure almost certainly includes both physical shipments and digital sales, and it'll take into account all three platforms on which the game is available as well. Still, five million since October is no mean feat!

If you're wondering exactly what Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero is, it's a fighting game that lets you do battle as one of over 180 Dragon Ball characters, including fan favorites like Goku, Vegeta, and Trunks (and variations thereof).

The game features characters from media like Dragon Ball Z, GT, and Super, as well as "selected Dragon Ball movies", and it'll also let you relive some of the series' most iconic moments "from the perspectives of eight characters".

After its release, Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero received updates adding features like splitscreen play across all of its stages, a new limited-time game mode, and plenty of gameplay tweaks and improvements.

Last month, the Hero of Justice DLC pack was released, bringing an additional eleven playable fighters to Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero, as well as a new costume and three bonus battles.

The DLC has not, however, met with a particularly positive reception, at least on Steam, where fans are complaining about the lack of variety between playable characters and the price of the pack.

In any case, Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero is available right now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. You can read our review of the game here.

item.title: Nintendo Profits Plummet as Switch Crosses 150m Sales
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/nintendo-profits-plummet-switch-150m

Nintendo has released its financial statement for the nine-month period between April and December 2024, and although the Switch has hit a new sales milestone, profits and sales are down overall.

In its financial presentation, Nintendo acknowledges that sales are down by 31.4% and net profit has fallen by 41.9% when compared to the same nine-month period last year, with sales of both hardware and software plummeting.

Despite this, the company also reveals that the Switch has reached 150 million lifetime sales, putting it within throwing distance of the Nintendo DS family (around 154 million) and perhaps even the all-time title holder, Sony's PS2 (160 million).

In terms of software sales, while overall figures fell, Super Mario Party Jamboree emerged as a big seller for Nintendo, reaching 6.17 million units sold in the nine-month time period.

Newcomer The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom sold almost 4 million copies, while Nintendo Switch Sports picked up another 2.63 million sales for itself. Incredibly, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe sold 5.38 million units during this time period. Could there still be Switch owners out there who don't own this game?

Of course, there's one big, massive exclamation point hanging over these figures, and that's the recent announcement of the Nintendo Switch 2, which will be unveiled in full during a Nintendo Direct showcase in April.

While the console itself wasn't revealed until January, Nintendo did reveal in May that a Switch 2 announcement would come before April 2025, suggesting that many consumers may have been holding off on buying a Switch in order to wait for the new machine to appear.

 With regards to its future, Nintendo points to a number of games it's releasing in the coming months, including the remastered version of Xenoblade Chronicles X, which is due to land in March.

The publisher also recommits to 2025 releases for Pokemon Legends: Z-A and Metroid Prime 4, both of which are apparently still slated to come to the original Switch (although I wouldn't be surprised to see Switch 2 ports for both).

You can check out Nintendo's full financial results document right here if you want to get super-nerdy with stats and figures.

item.title: Relic Knights is Getting A Relaunch Courtesy of Ignition Core Games
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/relic-knights-is-getting-relaunch-courtesy-of-ignition-core-games

Relic Knights is coming back under new management. The license for the anime-inspired miniatures skirmish game series, which went dormant after a controversial crowdfunding campaign, has been picked up by Ignition Core Games. Better still, it will be on sale at this year's Adepticon.

According to a press release, Ignition Core Games, Relic Knights will relaunch on the 27th of March at Adepticon at the Ignition Core Games/ Scale 75 USA booth.  They will offer a 2-Player Starter Set and three additional miniatures to expand the units in the starter set. Those miniatures are Combat Armor Cordelia, Alabaster Automata, and Infiltrator Candy.

The booth will host demo games across all four convention days. If you want to know how it plays before you buy, you'll have plenty of opportunities.

The releases will not end there. Throughout 2025, Relic Knights will have faction releases for Shattered Sword, Black Diamond, and Cerci Speed Circuit.  Everything offered will be available via direct sale, at conventions, or on Ignition Core Games' website from a stock of on-hand inventory.

A discount is possible if you were a backer of the Relic Knights Second Edition Kickstarter campaign. If you directly email Ignition Core Games, you can get a "steep discount" on anything in the product line you pledged for during the campaign.

To quote the press release directly, "It's not a perfect solution but we will provide you with your pledged items at the lowest prices possible."

This is important since the Relic Knights Second Edition Kickstarter campaign ended in disaster. It was originally developed by Soda Pop Miniatures and published by Ninja Division, the same studio behind Super Dungeon Explore.

Despite the campaign raising an impressive $386,826, production was stalled and stopped for several years. Ultimately, all Kickstarter Backers were left with nothing as Ninja Division filed for bankruptcy.

For those still interested in enjoying the anime-inspired action of Relic Knights, Adepticon is a few months away.
